div.h5: Charles Starkweather to J. M. Reinhardt Letter, 27 January 1959
div.div:
INSPECTED JAN 29 1959 NEBRASKA STATE PENITENTIARY
Charles Starkweather
Box 111 – 20396
Lincoln, Nebr.
Jan. 27, 1959
Dear Mr. Reinhardt:
I appreciate the fact that you wanted to edit my life story for me. but i can not agree to the way in which your going about it. so to keep from having feelings between us come to a disliking point in the near future. i would please like to have all of my manuscript return and i'm sorry if you have spent to much time on it, and if is cost you any trouble, and i assure you the money you have invested up to date, well [sic] be paid to you in full.
Please return immediately to me at the Nebraska State Penitentiary all containing parts of the original, and copies of the following chapters – 1, 2 and –3 of my manuscript. Also, in your possession, you have three, (3) large pictures, plus six, (6) small pictures, which are hand drawn by myself, and i wish those nine (9) in all. pictures are also return immediately along with the manuscript.
I'm not going to sell my story to no body, i'm a little disgusted over the headaches it's caused, but i hope to remain writing on it, and maybe we'll be able to get together on it later one, but not at this time.
Please return my manuscript, and pictures. at once, i'm impatiently waiting for their return, and as you well know my time is very limited.
Thank you—
Yours truely[sic]
Charles Starkweather

div.h5: Charles Starkweather to J. M. Reinhardt Letter, 27 April 1959
div.div:
Charles Starkweather
Box 111 – #20396
Lincoln, Nebraska
April 27, 1959
Dear Mr. Reinhardt:
I appreciate the fact that you have paid attention to my family and myself in the past but that does not give you an excuse for not returning my manuscript.
On Feb. 7, 1959 you made a RELEASE with my family releasing you from any previous agreements, also that release specified very clearly that you had no further interest or jurisdiction containing to that of my three chapters of my manuscripts which is now in your possession. You have informed us perviously [sic] that you had two typed, word for word copies made which should be sufficient to you, and which i nor the family have not disapprove of, but the release also clearly specified that you have no more need for my manuscript, and my family and i can not under–stand why you well[sic] not return the original script as you promised to do so at the close of the "Parade Magazin" publication on March 15, 1959. I wrote you a letter a few weeks before the Parade made these publication, stating that my desire was to have the manuscript return. And in reply, you told my family that you didn't have to return it until (30 days.). i assure you Mr. Reinhardt them 30 days have lapsed quite abit. I have quite abit of doubt in your character at this time. You have insisted to my family and myself several times that you're an honorable, trustworthy and a true–to–your–word person, but in my mind, there's doubt, but i insist on proof that you are what you say you are by the immediate return of my entire three chapters of my manuscript to me at this Nebraska State Penitentiary.
Respectfully yours
Charles Starkweather
I went to see Charles and explained that the m.s. was my copied-phototake - and would be returned to him (fo/a) & was returned promptly(?)
